At-a-Glance: Walk-away splits are fast but variable; controlled splits manage queen cells, timing, and outcomes—choose based on goals.
Why it Matters: Expands apiary and relieves swarm pressure.
Matching method to season improves success.
Objectives: Define goals (increase count vs selective improvement).
Use controlled splits when genetics/timing matter.
Track outcomes by method to refine SOP.
What Good Looks Like: Walk-away: equalising bees/brood; both halves can raise queen.
Controlled: queenright half + queenless half with chosen QC or introduced queen.
Follow-ups scheduled for cell culling and mating checks.
Step-by-Step: 1) Choose method; prep boxes and stands.
2) Allocate brood, food, and bees fairly; avoid moving the queen by mistake.
3) For controlled: select best open QC or add caged queen.
4) Recheck at day 7/14; feed as needed; log outcomes.
Seasonality & Climate: Best during strong nectar/queen mating windows.
Avoid long dearths or poor weather forecasts.
Data & Thresholds: Minimum frames of bees/brood per split.
Success rate target per method by month.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Queenless signs -> Provide frame with eggs or introduce queen.
Multiple casts -> Reduce to one QC; adjust entrances.
Weak halves -> Combine or boost with emerging brood.
Common Pitfalls: Accidentally moving queen to wrong half.
Leaving too many cells leading to casts.
Tools & Techniques: Queen clips, frame cages, feeders, entrance reducers.
Communications: State goal up front so helpers don’t mix methods.
Notes: Use a ‘split card’ taped to each box to prevent follow-up confusion.
